quoteLast: , they will appeare ſo ill-fauour’d, Their ſeruants run away, too, and leaue the pleaſure            45 Imperfect, and the reckoning all vnpay’d.
title: The Devil is an Ass
author: Jonson, Ben, 1573?-1637; Cook, Albert S. (Albert Stanburrough), 1853-1927 [Editor]; Johnson, William Savage, 1877-1942 [Editor]

quoteFirst: At the Casa Grande, our friends laughed at us immensely when we told them of the incident, and offered us
quoteLast: that he would come to ask for money within twenty-four hours. He came the same evening, and brought a wonderful story about his passport not being _en règle_, and that unless we could lend him ten dollars to bribe the police, he should be in a dreadful scrape.
title: Anahuac : or, Mexico and the Mexicans, Ancient and Modern
author: Tylor, Edward B. (Edward Burnett), 1832-1917

quoteFirst: They mounted fast enough; Lewis formed, and met the enemy in gallant style; and though there were ten, aye,
quoteLast: , possibly, he drove them back! To quote our friend, Major Hammond's words, "Lewis, of the Louisiana Cavalry, assumed command, struggled ably to preserve the guns (captured), and held his position fairly, until assistance arrived."
title:
The Humors of Falconbridge
A Collection of Humorous and Every Day Scenes
author: Falconbridge, 1818-1854

quoteFirst: Still, there are many chances against your having such an opportunity as this. Most days the hounds do _not_ run hard. When they do, you are perhaps so unfortunate as to lose your start, and finally, should everything else be in your favour, it is
quoteLast: you are riding the wrong horse!
title: Riding Recollections, 5th ed.
author: Whyte-Melville, G. J. (George John), 1821-1878; Giberne, Edgar, 1850-1889 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: the Child will not attempt it for a long time.

quoteFirst: Montcalm asked for an interview with Munro, and through Duncan, who acted as the latter's representative, explained that it was hopeless to think of holding the fort. General Webb had withdrawn the relieving force, and the English were outnumbered by about
quoteLast: . With chivalrous courtesy, the French general proposed that his brave enemies should march out with their arms and ammunition and all the honours of war. These conditions Munro sadly accepted.
title: The World's Greatest Books — Volume 02 — Fiction
